In AD 180, Spanish-Roman General Maximus Decimus Meridius leads the Roman army
to a decisive victory against the Germanic tribes near Vindobona, ending a long
war on the Roman frontier and winning the favor of Emperor Marcus Aurelius. The
emperor is already old and dying, and although he has a son, Commodus, he asks
Maximus to succeed him as a regent and turn Rome back into a republic
The emperor speaks with Commodus afterwards and attempts to explain his decision
A weeping Commodus retorts that Marcus Aurelius never valued his son, and smothers
the emperor.
